feed.title: WatInside
feed.subtitle: WatInside is a smart storage organization app that helps you find your things, faster. Scan handwritten or printed labels with our AI-powered app and instantly see what’s inside your boxes. Never forget what’s in your boxes again.

entry.content:
This video walks through:

  • Installing prerequisites and connecting your workspace
  • Key concepts and where they live in the UI
  • A brief demo of the most important features

entry.title: Tips and tricks
entry.summary: Power-user shortcuts and lesser-known features to speed up your work.

entry.title: Integrations
entry.content:
• Explore available integrations
  • Connect and authenticate
  • Map fields and sync data
entry.summary: Connect WatInside with your existing tools and data sources.

entry.title: Automations and alerts
entry.content:
• Create automation rules and triggers
  • Configure notification channels
  • Test and monitor workflows
entry.summary: Set up automated workflows, triggers, and notifications.

entry.title: Building dashboards
entry.content:
• Add charts and tables
  • Configure filters
  • Make views interactive for end users
entry.summary: Create insightful dashboards with charts, filters, and interactive components.

entry.title: Working with projects and data
entry.content:
In this video you will learn how to:

  • Create and structure projects
  • Import and manage datasets
  • Maintain resources efficiently
entry.summary: Organize projects, import datasets, and manage resources efficiently.

entry.title: Setup and installation
entry.content:
Steps covered:

1) Install prerequisites 2) Configure environment variables 3) Connect your workspace
entry.summary: Install prerequisites, configure your environment, and connect your workspace.

entry.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
entry.content:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.
entry.summary: You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.
